title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0001
text: What is the purpose of the 'super' keyword in Java?

options.text: To refer to the current object
To refer to the parent class object
To refer to static members
To refer to child class members

explanation: The 'super' keyword is used to refer to the parent class object.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0002
text: Which of the following can 'super' be used for?

options.text: Accessing parent class variables
Calling parent class methods
Calling parent class constructors
All of the above

explanation: The 'super' keyword can be used to access parent class variables, methods, and constructors.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0003
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and constructors?

options.text: It must be the first statement in a constructor
It can appear anywhere in a constructor
It can appear multiple times
It is optional in all constructors

explanation: When used to call a parent constructor, 'super()' must be the first statement in the subclass constructor.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0004
text: What happens if 'super()' is not explicitly called in a subclass constructor?

options.text: The compiler automatically inserts a call to the parent’s no-argument constructor
The program fails to compile
The parent constructor is never called
The child constructor is skipped

explanation: If 'super()' is not explicitly called, the compiler automatically inserts a call to the parent’s no-argument constructor.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0005
text: Which of the following is true about using 'super' to access variables?

options.text: It can access hidden variables from the parent class
It can access private variables of the parent class
It can access static variables only
It cannot access parent variables

explanation: The 'super' keyword can access hidden variables from the parent class if they are not private.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0006
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and method overriding?

options.text: It can call the overridden method of the parent class
It cannot call overridden methods
It can only call static methods
It can call private methods

explanation: The 'super' keyword can be used to call the overridden method of the parent class.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0007
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and private members?

options.text: It cannot access private members of the parent class
It can access private members directly
It can modify private members
It can override private methods

explanation: Private members of a parent class are not accessible using 'super'.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0008
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and static methods?

options.text: It cannot be used to call static methods
It can call static methods
It can override static methods
It can hide static methods

explanation: The 'super' keyword cannot be used to call static methods because static methods belong to the class, not the object.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0009
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and inheritance?

options.text: It is used to access members of the immediate parent class
It can access members of any ancestor class directly
It can access members of sibling classes
It can access members of unrelated classes

explanation: The 'super' keyword is used to access members of the immediate parent class only.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0010
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and constructor chaining?

options.text: It helps in calling parent constructors in a chain
It breaks the constructor chain
It skips parent constructors
It calls constructors randomly

explanation: The 'super' keyword helps in constructor chaining by calling parent constructors.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0011
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and multiple inheritance?

options.text: It works only with single inheritance
It supports multiple inheritance
It can call constructors from multiple parents
It is not allowed in inheritance

explanation: Java supports single inheritance, so 'super' works only with one immediate parent class.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0012
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and method overriding?

options.text: It can call the overridden method of the parent class
It cannot call overridden methods
It can only call static methods
It can call private methods

explanation: The 'super' keyword can be used to call the overridden method of the parent class.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0013
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and variable hiding?

options.text: It can access hidden variables from the parent class
It cannot access hidden variables
It can modify private variables
It can hide static variables

explanation: The 'super' keyword can access hidden variables from the parent class if they are not private.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0014
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and abstract classes?

options.text: It can call constructors of abstract classes
It cannot call constructors of abstract classes
It can instantiate abstract classes
It can override abstract methods

explanation: The 'super' keyword can call constructors of abstract classes, though abstract classes cannot be instantiated directly.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0015
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and interfaces?

options.text: It can call default methods from interfaces
It cannot be used with interfaces
It can call static methods from interfaces
It can access private methods of interfaces

explanation: The 'super' keyword can be used to call default methods from interfaces using InterfaceName.super.methodName().

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0016
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and constructors in inheritance?

options.text: It ensures the parent constructor is called before the child constructor
It ensures the child constructor is called first
It skips parent constructors
It calls constructors randomly

explanation: The 'super' keyword ensures that the parent constructor is called before the child constructor executes.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0017
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and method resolution?

options.text: It resolves to the immediate parent class method
It resolves to the grandparent class method
It resolves to the child class method
It resolves to the interface method

explanation: The 'super' keyword resolves to the immediate parent class method.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0018
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and multiple levels of inheritance?

options.text: It accesses only the immediate parent class
It can access any ancestor class directly
It can access sibling classes
It can access unrelated classes

explanation: The 'super' keyword can access only the immediate parent class members.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0019
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and constructor overloading?

options.text: It can call any overloaded constructor of the parent class
It can call only the default constructor
It cannot call overloaded constructors
It can call constructors of sibling classes

explanation: The 'super' keyword can call any overloaded constructor of the parent class by passing appropriate arguments.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0020
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and final methods?

options.text: It can call final methods of the parent class
It cannot call final methods
It can override final methods
It can modify final methods

explanation: The 'super' keyword can call final methods of the parent class, but they cannot be overridden.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0021
text: Which of the following is true about calling 'super()' in a subclass constructor?

options.text: It must be the first statement in the constructor
It can appear anywhere in the constructor
It can appear multiple times
It is optional and can be placed after other statements

explanation: When used to call a parent constructor, 'super()' must be the first statement in the subclass constructor.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0022
text: What happens if the parent class does not have a no-argument constructor and 'super()' is not explicitly called?

options.text: Compilation error occurs
Parent constructor is skipped
Default constructor is created automatically
Child constructor runs normally

explanation: If the parent class lacks a no-argument constructor and 'super()' is not explicitly called, a compilation error occurs.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0023
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and method overriding?

options.text: It can call the overridden method of the parent class
It cannot call overridden methods
It can only call static methods
It can call private methods

explanation: The 'super' keyword can be used to call the overridden method of the parent class.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0024
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and variable hiding?

options.text: It can access hidden variables from the parent class
It cannot access hidden variables
It can modify private variables
It can hide static variables

explanation: The 'super' keyword can access hidden variables from the parent class if they are not private.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0025
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and abstract classes?

options.text: It can call constructors of abstract classes
It cannot call constructors of abstract classes
It can instantiate abstract classes
It can override abstract methods

explanation: The 'super' keyword can call constructors of abstract classes, though abstract classes cannot be instantiated directly.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0026
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and interfaces?

options.text: It can call default methods from interfaces
It cannot be used with interfaces
It can call static methods from interfaces
It can access private methods of interfaces

explanation: The 'super' keyword can be used to call default methods from interfaces using InterfaceName.super.methodName().

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0027
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and constructor chaining?

options.text: It ensures the parent constructor is called before the child constructor
It ensures the child constructor is called first
It skips parent constructors
It calls constructors randomly

explanation: The 'super' keyword ensures that the parent constructor is called before the child constructor executes.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0028
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and method resolution?

options.text: It resolves to the immediate parent class method
It resolves to the grandparent class method
It resolves to the child class method
It resolves to the interface method

explanation: The 'super' keyword resolves to the immediate parent class method.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0029
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and multiple levels of inheritance?

options.text: It accesses only the immediate parent class
It can access any ancestor class directly
It can access sibling classes
It can access unrelated classes

explanation: The 'super' keyword can access only the immediate parent class members.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0030
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and constructor overloading?

options.text: It can call any overloaded constructor of the parent class
It can call only the default constructor
It cannot call overloaded constructors
It can call constructors of sibling classes

explanation: The 'super' keyword can call any overloaded constructor of the parent class by passing appropriate arguments.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0031
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and final methods?

options.text: It can call final methods of the parent class
It cannot call final methods
It can override final methods
It can modify final methods

explanation: The 'super' keyword can call final methods of the parent class, but they cannot be overridden.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0032
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and static context?

options.text: It cannot be used in static context
It can be used in static context
It can access static variables
It can call static methods

explanation: The 'super' keyword cannot be used in a static context because it refers to an instance of the parent class.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0033
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and object creation?

options.text: It is used implicitly when creating subclass objects
It creates objects directly
It replaces the 'new' keyword
It prevents object creation

explanation: The 'super' keyword is used implicitly when creating subclass objects to call the parent constructor.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0034
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and polymorphism?

options.text: It can be used to access overridden methods in the parent class
It disables polymorphism
It hides overridden methods
It can override static methods

explanation: The 'super' keyword can be used to access overridden methods in the parent class, supporting polymorphism.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0035
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and encapsulation?

options.text: It cannot access private members of the parent class
It can access private members directly
It can modify private members
It can override private methods

explanation: Private members of a parent class are not accessible using 'super', maintaining encapsulation.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0036
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and method hiding?

options.text: It can access hidden methods of the parent class
It cannot access hidden methods
It can override hidden methods
It can hide static methods

explanation: The 'super' keyword can access hidden methods of the parent class if they are not private.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0037
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and inheritance hierarchy?

options.text: It refers to the immediate parent class
It refers to the grandparent class
It refers to the child class
It refers to the interface

explanation: The 'super' keyword refers to the immediate parent class in the inheritance hierarchy.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0038
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and constructor chaining?

options.text: It ensures parent constructors are called before child constructors
It ensures child constructors are called first
It skips parent constructors
It calls constructors randomly

explanation: The 'super' keyword ensures that parent constructors are called before child constructors.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0039
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and object references?

options.text: It refers to the parent class object
It refers to the current object
It refers to the static context
It refers to the child class object

explanation: The 'super' keyword refers to the parent class object.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0040
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and method invocation?

options.text: It can invoke parent class methods
It can invoke child class methods
It can invoke static methods only
It cannot invoke any methods

explanation: The 'super' keyword can invoke parent class methods, including overridden ones.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0041
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and constructor calls?

options.text: It can call parameterized constructors of the parent class
It can call only default constructors
It cannot call constructors
It can call constructors of sibling classes

explanation: The 'super' keyword can call parameterized constructors of the parent class by passing arguments.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0042
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and method overriding?

options.text: It can call the overridden method of the parent class
It cannot call overridden methods
It can only call static methods
It can call private methods

explanation: The 'super' keyword can be used to call the overridden method of the parent class.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0043
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and inheritance depth?

options.text: It always refers to the immediate parent class
It can refer to any ancestor class
It can refer to sibling classes
It can refer to unrelated classes

explanation: The 'super' keyword always refers to the immediate parent class in the inheritance chain.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0044
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and constructor chaining?

options.text: It ensures parent constructors are called before child constructors
It ensures child constructors are called first
It skips parent constructors
It calls constructors randomly

explanation: The 'super' keyword ensures that parent constructors are called before child constructors.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0045
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and method access?

options.text: It can access protected and public methods of the parent class
It can access private methods
It can access static methods
It can access methods of sibling classes

explanation: The 'super' keyword can access protected and public methods of the parent class.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0046
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and object references?

options.text: It refers to the parent class object
It refers to the current object
It refers to the static context
It refers to the child class object

explanation: The 'super' keyword refers to the parent class object.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0047
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and constructor invocation order?

options.text: Parent constructors are called before child constructors
Child constructors are called before parent constructors
Constructors are called randomly
Constructors are not related

explanation: Parent constructors are always called before child constructors using 'super'.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0048
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and method overriding?

options.text: It can call the overridden method of the parent class
It cannot call overridden methods
It can only call static methods
It can call private methods

explanation: The 'super' keyword can be used to call the overridden method of the parent class.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0049
text: Which of the following is true about 'super' and inheritance?

options.text: It is used to access members of the immediate parent class
It can access members of any ancestor class directly
It can access members of sibling classes
It can access members of unrelated classes

explanation: The 'super' keyword is used to access members of the immediate parent class only.

title: JavaOOPSuperKeyword - Q0050
text: Which of the following best describes the 'super' keyword?

options.text: A reference variable used to refer to the immediate parent class object
A keyword used to refer to the current object
A keyword used to refer to static members
A keyword used to refer to child class members

explanation: The 'super' keyword is a reference variable used to refer to the immediate parent class object.
